[[Seemingly unrelated regressions]] | awards = }} '''Arnold Zellner''' (January 2, 1927 – August 11, 2010) was an American [[economist]] and [[statistician]] specializing in the fields of [[Bayesian probability]] and [[econometrics]]. Zellner contributed pioneering work in the field of [[Bayesian analysis]] and [[econometric model]]ing. In Bayesian analysis, Zellner not only provided many applications of it but also a new [[information theory|information-theoretic]] derivation of rules that are 100% efficient information processing rules—this class includes Bayes's theorem. In [[econometric modeling]], he, in association with {{ill|nl|Franz Palm}}, developed the structural time-series approach for constructing new models and for checking the adequacy of old models. In addition, he was involved in many important applied econometric and statistical studies. Born in [[Brooklyn, New York]], to [[Ukrainian American|Ukrainian immigrant]] parents,{{cite web |last=Aybar |first= Pinar |url=https://nature.berkeley.edu/blogs/news/2010/08/in_memoriam_of_arnold_zellner.php |title=In Memoriam of Dr. Arnold Zellner |date=August 12, 2010 |publisher=College of Natural Resources, University of California, Berkeley }} Zellner earned his [[Bachelor of Arts|A.B.]] in [[physics]] from [[Harvard University]] in 1949 and his [[Ph.D.]] in [[economics]] from the [[University of California, Berkeley]], under supervision of [[George Kuznets]], in 1957. He holds honorary degrees from the [[Autonomous University of Madrid]] in Spain, the [[Universidade Técnica de Lisboa]] in [[Portugal]], the [[University of Kiel]] in [[Germany]], and the [[Erasmus University Rotterdam|Erasmus School of Economics]] at [[Erasmus University Rotterdam]] in the [[Netherlands]]. He was H.G.B. Alexander Distinguished Service Professor Emeritus of Economics and Statistics at the Graduate School of Business of the [[University of Chicago]]. He was the founder of the [[International Society for Bayesian Analysis]] and also served as [[List of presidents of the American Statistical Association|President]] of the [[American Statistical Association]] in 1991. He died on August 11, 2010, in his home in [[Hyde Park, Chicago]].{{cite web |url=https://news.uchicago.edu/news.php?asset_id=2064|title=Arnold Zellner, 1927–2010, a pioneer of modern econometrics |publisher=University of Chicago |date=August 13, 2010}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://faculty.chicagobooth.edu/arnold.zellner/more/ Arnold Zellner's webpage] *[http://korora.econ.yale.edu/et/interview/zellner.pdf ET Interviews: Professor Arnold Zellner] on the [http://korora.econ.yale.edu/et/ Econometric Theory] page. *[http://www.strategy2market.com/downloads/InterviewwithArnoldZellner.pdf ''An Interview with Arnold Zellner''] (2004), Kathy Morrison *{{MathGenealogy|id=148660 }} {{Authority control}} {{Persondata | NAME = Zellner, Arnold | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American economist | DATE OF BIRTH = January 2, 1927 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Brooklyn, New York, USA | DATE OF DEATH = August 11, 2010 | PLACE OF DEATH = Chicago, Illinois, USA }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zellner, Arnold}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:American people of Ukrainian descent]] [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:Econometricians]] [[Category:American economists]] [[Category:American statisticians]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Presidents of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:Bayesian statisticians]] [[Category:Bayesian econometricians]] {{US-economist-stub}}
